StringWithMarkup.String: Aniline's production and use as a chemical intermediate in the synthesis of rubber accelerators and antioxidants, dyes and intermediates, photographic chemicals, isocyanates for urethane foams, pharmaceuticals, explosives, petroleum refining, diphenylamine, phenolics, herbicides, and fungicides(1) and its use as a solvent and in the manufacture of dyes, medicinals, resins, varnishes, perfumes, and shoe blacks(2) may result in its release to the environment through various waste streams(SRC). Aniline has been identified as a constituent of tobacco, tobacco smoke, and tobacco smoke substitute(3).

Reference: (1) Catallo WJ, Junk T; J Environ Qual 34: 1746-54 (2005)

StringWithMarkup.String: Aniline was identified as a metabolite of benzothiazole degradation in estuarine sediment(1).

Section.Description: Environmental fate describes where this chemical goes when it gets out into the environment and how it might be chemically transformed in that process.  This section may provide information on multiple types of environmental fates of the chemical (e.g., aquatic fate, terrestrial fate, and atmospheric fate).

Reference: (1) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 17-28 (1983)
(2) Gawlik BM et al; Chemosphere 36: 2903-19 (1998)
(3) Gawlik BM et al; Chemosphere 41: 1337-47 (2000)
(4) Perrin DD; Dissociation Constants of Organic Bases in Aqueous Solution. IUPAC Chem Data Ser. Butterworth, London (1972)
(5) Doucette WJ; pp. 141-188 in Handbook of Property Estimation Methods for Chemicals. Boethling RS, Mackay D, eds. Boca Raton, FL: Lewis Publ (2000)
(6) Bollag JM et al; J Agric Food Chem 26: 1302-6 (1978)
(7) Adrian P et al; Toxicol Environ Chem 20-21: 109-20 (1989)
(8) Jayasinghe DS et al; Environ Sci Technol 26: 2275-81 (1992) https://www.safe.nite.go.jp/english/db.html
(9) Daubert TE, Danner RP; Physical and Thermodynamic Properties of Pure Chemicals Data Compilation. Washington, DC: Taylor and Francis (2002)
(10) NITE; Chemical Risk Information Platform (CHRIP). Biodegradation and Bioconcentration. Tokyo, Japan: Natl Inst Tech Eval.

StringWithMarkup.String: TERRESTRIAL FATE: Based on a classification scheme(1), Koc values in the range of 43.8-497.7 in five European soils(2) and 8-137 in five second-generation European reference soils(3), indicate that aniline is expected to have high to moderate mobility in soil(SRC). The pKa of aniline is 4.60(4), indicating that this compound may partially exist in the cation form in the environment and cations generally adsorb more strongly to soils containing organic carbon and clay than their neutral counterparts(5). Anilines are expected to bind strongly to humus or organic matter in soils due to the high reactivity of the aromatic amino group(6,7), suggesting that mobility may be much lower in some soils. Volatilization of aniline from moist soil surfaces may be an important fate process(SRC) given a Henry's Law constant of 2.02X10-6 atm-cu m/mole(8). Aniline is not expected to volatilize from dry soil surfaces(SRC) based upon a vapor pressure of 0.667 mm Hg at 25 °C(9). An 85% of theoretical BOD(NH3) after 2 weeks using activated sludge in the Japanese MITI test(10) indicates that biodegradation is an important environmental fate process in soil(SRC).

Reference: Dao TH, Lavy TL; Soil Sci 143 (1): 66-72 (1987)

StringWithMarkup.String: TERRESTRIAL FATE: The effects of low temperature and accelerated soil solution contact on soil adsorption of labile organic chemicals were investigated in lab experiments. Kinetics of adsorption and degradation were measured for (14)C-labeled aniline, benzoic acid, phenol, and diuron in the soln phase at 3 and 22 °C. In the initial stages of reaction, the adsorption of all 4 chemicals was instantaneous at both temperatures under accelerated soil and solution mixing. A steady state was observed after the onset of equilibrium for the adsorption reaction for all compounds within 10-30 minutes. Its length varied according to the expected order of susceptibility to microbial degradation, ie, diuron > aniline > phenol greater than or equal to benzoate. The steady state period without or in combination with low temperature could be used to obtain adsorption measurements in active microbial systems. Minimal interference from solute transformations in the solution phase would be expected from soil microorganisms.

Reference: (1) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 17-28 (1983)
(2) Gawlik BM et al; Chemosphere 36: 2903-19 (1998)
(3) Gawlik BM et al; Chemosphere 41: 1337-47 (2000)
(4) Lyman WJ et al; Handbook of Chemical Property Estimation Methods. Washington, DC: Amer Chem Soc pp. 15-1 to 15-29 (1990)
(5) Jayasinghe DS et al; Environ Sci Technol 26: 2275-81 (1992)
(6) Perrin DD; Dissociation Constants of Organic Bases in Aqueous Solution; IUPAC Chemical Data Series; Supplement; London Buttersworth (1972)
(7) Franke C et al; Chemosphere 29: 1501-14 (1994)
(8) Freitag D et al; Ecotox Environ Safety 6: 60-81 (1982)

(9) NITE; Chemical Risk Information Platform (CHRIP). Biodegradation and Bioconcentration. Tokyo, Japan: Natl Inst Tech Eval. Available from, as of March 23, 2018: https://www.safe.nite.go.jp/english/db.html
(10) Kondo M; Simulation studies of degradation of chemicals in the environment. Environment Agency. Off Health Studies Japan (1978)

StringWithMarkup.String: AQUATIC FATE: Based on a classification scheme(1), Koc values in the range of 43.8-497.7 in five European soils(2) and 8-137 in five second-generation European reference soils(3), indicate that aniline is not expected to adsorb to suspended solids and sediment(SRC). Volatilization of the neutral species from water surfaces may be expected(4) based upon a Henry's Law constant of 2.02X10-6 atm-cu m/mole(5). A pKa of 4.60(6) indicates aniline may exist partially in the cation form at pH values of 5 to 9 and, therefore, volatilization from water surfaces is not expected to be an important fate process for the ionized species(SRC). According to a classification scheme(7), an experimental BCF of less than 1(8), suggests the potential for bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is low(SRC). An 85% of theoretical BOD(NH3) after 2 weeks using activated sludge in the Japanese MITI test(9) indicates that biodegradation is an important environmental fate process in water(SRC). Aniline reached 19.3% degradation after 5 hours of sunlight irradiation(10), suggesting that photolysis may be an important process in sunlit water surfaces(SRC).

Reference: Hwang HM et al; Water Res 21 (3): 309-16 (1987)

StringWithMarkup.String: AQUATIC FATE: The relative importance in estuarine water of photolysis and microbial degradation on aniline and a series of chloroanilines (p-chloroaniline, 2,4-dichloroaniline, and 2,4,5-trichloroaniline) was determined. Photolysis was important for all compounds with photo-transformation half-lives in surface estuarine water ranging from 2 to 125 hr. Photolysis rates were lower in estuarine water relative to distilled water. There was no microbial degradation of chloroanilines during short term incubations (up to 3 days). The half-lives of aniline in estuarine water was 27 and 173 hr in the light and dark (microbial), respectively. Photolysis and microbial degradation rate constants decreased in winter. The winter decrease in photolysis rates correlated to a decrease in surface irradiance while the microbial degradation decrease correlated to the temperature decrease. There was rapid microbial degradation of the chloroanilines and aniline photoproducts. The mineralization of photoproducts of chloroanilines was carried out by bacteria, while microbes larger than 3 um, e.g. algae, were responsible for the bioaccumulation of the compounds.

Reference: (1) Bidleman TF; Environ Sci Technol 22: 361-367 (1988)

(2) Daubert TE, Danner RP; Physical and Thermodynamic Properties of Pure Chemicals Data Compilation. Washington, DC: Taylor and Francis (2002) US EPA; Estimation Program Interface (EPI) Suite. Ver. 4.11. Nov, 2012. Available from, as of Mar 26, 2018: https://www2.epa.gov/tsca-screening-tools

(3) Kwok ESC, Atkinson R; Estimation of hydroxyl radical reaction rate constants for gas-phase organic compounds using a structure-reactivity relationship: an update. Riverside, CA: Univ CA, Statewide Air Pollut Res Ctr. CMA Contract No. ARC-8.0-OR (1994)

(4) NIST; NIST Chemistry WebBook. Aniline (62-53-3). NIST Standard Reference Database No. 69, Feb 2015 Release. Washington, DC: US Sec Commerce. Available from, as of March 26, 2018: https://webbook.nist.gov

StringWithMarkup.String: ATMOSPHERIC FATE: According to a model of gas/particle partitioning of semivolatile organic compounds in the atmosphere(1), aniline, which has a vapor pressure of 0.667 mm Hg at 25 °C(2), is expected to exist solely as a vapor in the ambient atmosphere. Vapor-phase aniline is degraded in the atmosphere by reaction with photochemically-produced hydroxyl radicals(SRC); the half-life for this reaction in air is estimated to be 4 hours(SRC), calculated from its rate constant of 1.1X10-10 cu cm/molecule-sec at 25 °C(3). Aniline contains chromophores that absorb at wavelengths >290 nm(4) and, therefore, is expected to be susceptible to direct photolysis by sunlight, since sunlight consists of wavelengths above 290 nm(SRC).

Section.Description: This section provides information on environmental biodegradation for this compound. Biodegradation is the breakdown of organic matter by microorganisms, such as bacteria and fungi.  An important measure of biodegradability of wastewater is the biochemical oxygen demand (BOD), which is the amount of dissolved oxygen (DO) needed (i.e. demanded) by aerobic biological organisms to break down organic material present in a given water sample at certain temperature over a specific time period.

Reference: (1) Pitter P; Water Res 10: 231-5 (1976)
(2) Helfgott TB et al; An Index Of Refractory Organics USEPA-600/2-77-174 (1977)
(3) Gerike P, Fischer WK; Ecotox Environ Safety 3: 159-73 (1979)
(4) Kawasaki M; Ecotox Environ Safety 4: 444-54 (1980)
(5) Zahn R, Wellens H; Z Wasser Abwasser Forsch 13: 1-7 (1980)
(6) Means JL, Anderson SJ; Water Air Soil Pollut 16: 301-15 (1981)
(7) Baird R et al; J Water Pollut Control Fed 49: 1609-15 (1977)
(8) Korte F, Klein W; Ecotox Environ Safety 6: 311-27 (1982)
(9) Gilbert PA, Lee CM; pp. 34-45 in Biotransformation And Fate Of Chemicals In The Aquatic Environment; Maki AW et al eds; Univ Mich, Pellston, MI (1980)
(10) Bilyk A et al; Pr Nauk Inst Inz Sanit Wodnej Politech Wroclaw pp. 3-32 (1971)
(11) Schefer W, Walechli O; Z Wasser Abwasser Forch 13: 205-9 (1980)
(12) Freitag D et al; Ecotox Environ Safety 6: 60-81 (1982)
(13) Brown D, Laboureur P; Chemosphere 12: 405-14 (1983)
(14) Hallas LE, Alexander M; Appl Environ Microbiol 45: 1234-41 (1983)

(15) NITE; Chemical Risk Information Platform (CHRIP). Biodegradation and Bioconcentration. Tokyo, Japan: Natl Inst Tech Eval. Available from, as of March 15, 2018: https://www.safe.nite.go.jp/english/db.html

StringWithMarkup.String: AEROBIC: Aniline is a benchmark chemical for aerobic biodegradability tests and there are abundant data on its biodegradation. Degradation is frequently 90-100% in laboratory tests utilizing activated sludge or sewage seed lasting from 3 to 28 days with acclimation not always being required(1-14). Aniline, present at 100 mg/L, reached 85% of its theoretical BOD(NH3) in 2 weeks using an activated sludge inoculum at 30 mg/L in the Japanese MITI test(15).

Reference: (1) Calamari D et al; Chemosphere 9: 753-62 (1980)
(2) Subba-Rao RV et al; Appl Environ Microbiol 43: 1139-50 (1982)
(3) El-Dib MA, Aly OA; Water Res 10: 1055-9 (1976)
(4) Kondo M; Simulation Studies Of Degradation Of Chemicals In The Environment. Environment Agency. Off Health Studies Japan (1978)
(5) Zoeteman BCJ et al; Chemosphere 9: 231-49 (1980)
(6) Osaki Y et al; Eisei Kagaku 5: 411-17 (1990)
(7) Nishihara T et al; J Appl Microbiol 82: 441-47 (1997)

StringWithMarkup.String: AEROBIC: Aniline is completely degraded by bacteria in river mud in 20 days(1). 75-99% Mineralization occurred in 21 days in water from an oligotrophic lake(2) and 40-60% of the aniline degraded in 1 day in river water and seawater when incubated at 30 °C(4). Degradation occurred in Nile River water after a 3-day lag(3). The half-life of aniline in the Rhine River was 2.30 days as determined by concentration reduction between sampling points(5). Aniline was biodegraded approximately 100% in upper surface water from the Naka River and approximately 70% in lower reaches over a 7 day incubation period(6). Aniline was completely degraded by pond water near an industrial factory in Osaka, Japan over a 7 day incubation period, but was not degraded in water from a non-polluted botanical pond and rice paddy(7).

Reference: (1) Suess A et al; Bayerisches Landwireschaftersches Jahrbuch 55: 565-70 (1978)
(2) Zoeteman BCJ et al; Chemosphere 9: 231-49 (1980)
(3) Alexander M, Lustigman BK; J Agric Food Chem 14: 410-3 (1966)
(4) Aoki K et al; Agric Biol Chem 46: 2563-71 (1982)
(5) Kondo M; Simulation Studies Of Degradation Of Chemicals In The Environment. Environment Agency. Office Of Health Studies Japan (1978)
(6) Smith RV, Rosazza JP; Arch Biochem Biophys 161: 551-8 (1974)
(7) Surovtseva EG et al; Dokl Akad Nauk SSSR 237: 220-3 (1977)
(8) Subramanian V et al; Indian Inst Sci J 60: 143-78 (1978)

StringWithMarkup.String: AEROBIC: Aniline is degraded by many common species of bacteria and fungi found in soil(4-6) and acetanilide, 2-hydroxyacetanilide, 4-hydroxyaniline and catechol are reported metabolites(6-8). The rate of degradation in 4 soils reached a maximum value after one week and declined to a low value after 2 weeks(1). However, approx 60% of the aniline was bound to the soil and probably unavailable(1). In <1 yr, 39% of aniline in Rhine River water was removed by bank filtration(2), which would involve both biodegradation and adsorption. Aniline is completely degraded by a soil inoculum in 4 days(3).

Reference: (1) Ingerslev F, Nyholm N; Ecotoxicol Environ Saf 45: 274-83 (2000)
(2) Reuschenbach P et al; Warwe Res 37: 1571-82 (2003)
(3) Bornick H et al; Water Res 35: 619-24 (2001)
(4) Ahtiainen J et al; Chemosphere 51: 529-37 (2003)
(5) Torang L et al; Chemosphere 49: 1257-65 (2002)

StringWithMarkup.String: AEROBIC: Shake-flask surface water die away biodegradability tests found that aniline was degraded with little or no lag periods and relatively short half-lives of 10-20 days(1). The results of various OECD 301 biodegradation tests were as follows (rate constant/day)(2): DOC die away (1.71), B Sturm test (0.30), F Oxitop (0.74), F Sapromat (0.86). In a laboratory biodegradation study using unfiltered water from the Elbe River and a circulating column, aniline was found to have very good biodegradability with a half-life of 1 hr(3). In biodegradation studies using shake-flask batch tests, the half-life of aniline using relatively pristine natural Finish waters ranged from 10-150 days while half-life using activated sludge inoculum or urban water was 5-8 days(4). The results of 38 shake-flask batch tests using Rhine River water found aniline to have an average biodegradation rate constant of 1.5/day at 15 °C and 2.0/day at 20 °C(5).
For more Environmental Biodegradation (Complete) data for Aniline (7 total), please visit the HSDB record page.

Section.Description: Abiotic degradation is a process by which a chemical substance is broken down into smaller molecules by non-biotic means (e.g., hydrolysis, photolysis, and oxidation).

Reference: (1) Kwok ESC, Atkinson R; Estimation of hydroxyl radical reaction rate constants for gas-phase organic compounds using a structure-reactivity relationship: an update. Riverside, CA: Univ CA, Statewide Air Pollut Res Ctr. CMA Contract No. ARC-8.0-OR (1994)
(2) Atkinson R; J Phys Chem Ref Data Monograph 2 (1994)
(3) Atkinson R, Carter WPL; Chem Rev 84: 437-70 (1984)
(4) Torang L et al; Chemosphere 49: 1257-65 (2002)

(5) NIST; NIST Chemistry WebBook. Aniline (62-53-3). NIST Standard Reference Database No. 69, Feb 2015 Release. Washington, DC: US Sec Commerce. Available from, as of March 26, 2018: https://webbook.nist.gov
(6) Meallier P et al; Ann Chim 4: 15-28 (1969)

StringWithMarkup.String: The rate constant for the vapor-phase reaction of aniline with photochemically-produced hydroxyl radicals has been reported as 1.1X10-10 cu cm/molecule-sec at 25 °C(1). This corresponds to an atmospheric half-life of about 4 hours at an atmospheric concentration of 5X10+5 hydroxyl radicals per cu cm(SRC). The rate constant for the vapor-phase reaction of aniline with nitrate radicals has been reported as 1.5X10-16 cu cm/molecule-sec at 25 °C(2). This corresponds to an atmospheric half-life of about 233 days at an atmospheric concentration of 2.4X10+8 nitrate radicals per cu cm(3). The rate constant for the vapor-phase reaction of aniline with ozone has been reported as 1.1X10-18 cu cm/molecule-sec at 25 °C(2). This corresponds to an atmospheric half-life of about 10 days at an atmospheric concentration of 7X10+11 ozone molecules per cu cm(3). Aniline has a reported aqueous hydrolysis half-life of greater than 50 years(4), suggesting that hydrolysis is not an important environmental fate process. Aniline contains chromophores that absorb at wavelengths >290 nm(5,6) and, therefore, is expected to be susceptible to direct photolysis by sunlight, since sunlight consists of wavelengths above 290 nm(SRC).

Reference: (1) Meallier P et al; Ann Chim 4: 15-28 (1969)
(2) Kondo M; Simulation studies of degradation of chemicals in the environment. Environment agency. Office of health studies Japan (1978)
(3) Draper WM, Crosby DG; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 12: 121-6 (1983)
(4) Kotzias D et al; Naturwissenschaften 69: 444-5(1982)
(5) Freitag D et al; Ecotox Environ Safety 6: 601-81 (1982)
(6) Zepp RG et al; Chemosphere 10: 109-17 (1981)
(7) Zepp RG, Schlotzhauer PF; Environ Sci Technol 17: 462-8 (1983)
(8) Torang L et al; Chemosphere 49: 1257-65 (2002)

StringWithMarkup.String: Aniline reached 19.3% degradation after 5 hours irradiation in July sunlight. However the rate decreased with increasing concentration of aniline(2). Other studies report 0.7% oxidant formation after 4 hours exposure to sunlight(3), and a half-life of 0.2 hours during exposure to light >290 nm in the laboratory(4). Humic acids photosensitize the reaction of aniline in water(6); the half-life in distilled water was 1 week whereas it was 4-8 hours in May Georgia sunshine in the near-surface black water from the Aucilla River(6). The presence of various species of algae can increase the photodegradation rates by factors of 4-50 over that in distilled water(7). When adsorbed on silica gel, 46.5% mineralization occurs in 17 hours upon irradiation with light >290 nm(5). Aniline has a reported aqueous hydrolysis half-life of greater than 50 years(8).

Reference: (1) Zechner J et al; Z Phys Chem 102: 137-50 (1976)
(2) Zepp RG et al; Chemosphere 10: 109-17 (1981)
(3) Kondo M; Simulation Studies of Degradation Of Chemicals In The Environment. Environment Agency. Office Of Health Studies Japan (1978)
(4) Suzuki J et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 31: 79-84 (1983)
(5) Gitchell A et al; J Air Pollut Control Assoc 24: 357-61 (1974)
(6) Nguyen YV, Phillips CR; Chemosphere 4: 125-30 (1975)
(7) Freitag D et al; Chemosphere 14: 1589-1616 (1985)

StringWithMarkup.String: Aniline is oxidized on exposure to sunlight in air forming products such as hydrazobenzene, 4-aminodiphenylamine, 2-aminodiphenylamine, benzidine and azobenzene(1,2). Variability in results may be due to aeration of the water as well as substrate concentration since shaking increases the rate of degradation(3). In the presence of nitrite ions, photolytic products formed are mutagenic using the Ames assay(4). In the atmosphere, aniline inhibits the conversion of nitric oxide (NO) to nitrogen dioxide (NO2) and photochemical smog formation(5,6). 46.5 % degradation by light was reported at wavelengths above 290 nm(7).

Section.Description: This section provides information on environmental bioconcentration for this compound.  Bioconcentration is the accumulation of a chemical in or on an organism when the source of chemical is solely water. Bioconcentration is a term that was created for use in the field of aquatic toxicology. Bioconcentration can also be defined as the process by which a chemical concentration in an aquatic organism exceeds that in water as a result of exposure to a waterborne chemical.

Reference: (1) Freitag D et al; Ecotox Environ Safety 6: 60-81 (1982)
(2) Franke C et al; Chemosphere 29: 1501-14 (1994)
(3) Geyer H et al; Chemosphere 10: 1307-13 (1981)

StringWithMarkup.String: A BCF of less than 10 was measured for aniline using golden orfes (Leuciscus idus melanotus) which were exposed over a 3-day period(1). According to a classification scheme(2), this BCF suggests the potential for bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is low(SRC). The BCF for algae (Chlorelle fusca var. vacuolate) was reported as 4(1,3).

Section.Description: Sorption to soils and sediments is an important factor on the transport and fate of organic contaminants in the environment.  The soil/water adsorption coefficient, also known as solid-water distribution coefficient (Kd), measures the amount of chemical substance adsorbed onto soil per amount of water.  Since adsorption occurs predominantly by partition into the soil organic matter, it is more useful to normalize the Kd value to the organic carbon content of a soil and express the distribution coefficient in Koc (organic carbon normalized distribution coefficient).  The greater the Kd (or Koc) value, the less likely a chemical will leach or contribute to runoff.  A very high value means it is strongly adsorbed onto soil and organic matter and does not move throughout the soil.

Reference: (1) Gawlik BM et al; Chemosphere 36: 2903-19 (1998)
(2) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 17-28 (1983)
(3) Perrin DD; Dissociation Constants of Organic Bases in Aqueous Solution. IUPAC Chem Data Ser. Butterworth, London (1972)
(4) Doucette WJ; pp. 141-188 in Handbook of Property Estimation Methods for Chemicals. Boethling RS, Mackay D, eds. Boca Raton, FL: Lewis Publ (2000)
(5) Bollag JM et al; J Agric Food Chem 26: 1302-6 (1978)
(6) Adrian P et al; Toxicol Environ Chem 20-21: 109-20 (1989)

StringWithMarkup.String: The Koc of aniline has been measured as a range of 43.8 to 497.7, using 5 European soils(1). According to a classification scheme(2), this Koc range suggests that aniline is expected to have very high to moderate mobility in soil. The pKa of aniline is 4.60(3), indicating that this compound may exist partially in cation form in the environment and cations generally adsorb more strongly to soils containing organic carbon and clay than their neutral counterparts(4). However, anilines are expected to bind strongly to humus or organic matter in soils due to the high reactivity of the aromatic amino group(5,6), suggesting that mobility may be much lower in some soils(SRC).

Reference: (1) Pillai P et al; Chemosphere 11: 299-317 (1982)
(2) Means JC; Amer Chem Soc 186th Natl Mtg 23: 250-1 (1982)
(3) Bailey GW et al; Soil Sci Soc Amer Proc 32: 222-34 (1968)
(4) Lee LS et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 16: 1575-82 (1997)
(5) Kordel W et al; Chemosphere 35: 107-19 (1997)
(6) Gawlik BM et al; Chemosphere 41: 1337-47 (2000)
(7) Weber EJ et al; Environ Sci Technol 35: 2470-75 (2001)
(8) Donaldson FP, Nyman MC; Chemosphere 65: 854-62 (2006)
(9) Fabrega-Duque JR et al; Environ Sci Technol 34: 1687-93 (2000)

StringWithMarkup.String: The Koc of aniline in 2 silt loams was measured as 130 and 410 with the higher value occurring in the more acidic soil(1). The Koc of aniline in colloidal organic carbon from groundwater (pH 6.5) was reported as 3,870(2). The adsorption constant for adsorption to H-montmorillonite (pH 8.35) and Na-montmorillonite (pH 6.8) is 1,300 and 130(3). The Koc of aniline in 3 silt-clay loams were 269 (pH 4.4), 48 (pH 6.5) and 16 (pH 7.2)(4). A mean Koc value of 55 was determined for aniline in 4 sewage sludge samples(5). The Koc in five second-generation reference EUROSOILS was 8, 32, 19, 27 and 137(6). In a sorption study using pond sediment from Cherokee Park pond in Athens GA, the sorption kinetics of aniline were characterized by a rapid initial loss of aniline from the aqueous phase followed by a much slower rate of disappearance; the initial sorption was a reversible cation-exchange followed by a slower covalent-binding. It was shown that at pH values greater than the pKa, sorption kinetics were slower than at pH 3.75 (rate constants of 4.53-7.95/hr above versus 13.3 below)(7). The sorption of aniline in a silty clay soil after 24 hours was not solely dependent on cation exchange, solubility was a consideration, and passing rainwater through a soil column had no effect on the sorption to the silty clay soil(8). Using four Indiana soils and one Iowa soil, abiotic loss of aniline from the aqueous phase to the soil phase occurred with an initial rapid loss due to reversible mass transfer processes followed by a slow loss due to irreversible reactions(9).

Section.Description: Volatilization of chemicals from water/soil is the transfer of the chemical as a gas through the water-air or soil-air interface under environmental conditions

Reference: (1) Jayasinghe DS et al; Environ Sci Technol 26: 2275-81 (1992)
(2) Lyman WJ et al; Handbook of Chemical Property Estimation Methods. Washington, DC: Amer Chem Soc pp. 15-1 to 15-29 (1990)
(3) Daubert TE, Danner RP; Physical and Thermodynamic Properties of Pure Chemicals Data Compilation Washington, DC: Taylor and Francis, (2002)

StringWithMarkup.String: The Henry's Law constant for aniline is reported as 2.02X10-6 atm-cu m/mole(1). This Henry's Law constant indicates that the neutral species is expected to volatilize from water surfaces(2). Based on this Henry's Law constant, the volatilization half-life from a model river (1 m deep, flowing 1 m/sec, wind velocity of 3 m/sec)(2) is estimated as 17.6 days(SRC). The volatilization half-life from a model lake (1 m deep, flowing 0.05 m/sec, wind velocity of 0.5 m/sec)(2) is estimated as 131 days(SRC). Aniline's Henry's Law constant indicates that volatilization from moist soil surfaces may occur(SRC). Aniline has a vapor pressure of 0.667 mm Hg at 25 °C(3) and exists as a liquid under environmental conditions; therefore, aniline may volatilize from dry soil.

Section.Description: Concentrations of this chemical in water in various stages of hydrologic cycle (e.g., drinking water, ground water, surface water, and rain/snow).

Reference: (1) Stuermer DH et al; Environ Sci Technol 16: 582-7 (1982)
(2) Pereira WE et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 2: 283-94 (1983)
(3) Holm JV et al; Environ Sci Technol 29: 1415-20 (1995)
(4) National Water Quality Monitoring Council. Water Quality Data. Aniline. Available from as of March 16, 2018: https://www.waterqualitydata.us/portal

StringWithMarkup.String: GROUNDWATER: Aniline was detected at a concentration of 36 ppb in an aquifer at the Hoe Creek underground coal gasification site in Wyoming, sample dates were not provided(1). Aniline was identified, not quantified, in October 1981 at St. Louis Park, MN in a shallow aquifer contaminated by coal-tar wastes(2). Aniline was detected in groundwater near a landfill in Denmark at concentrations of less than 10 to 720 ug/L, sample dates were not provided(3). Water quality data compiled from the Retrieval (STORET) Data Warehouse and the USGS National Water Information System (NWIS) reports monitoring data for aniline; this chemical was detected at concentrations of 5 ug/L in 44 samples and not detected in 100 groundwater samples collected by the Arizona Department of Environmental Quality between February 2013 and October 2015(4).

Reference: (1) Lucas SV; GC/MS Analysis of Drinking Water Concentrates and Advanced Waste Treatment Concentrates: Vol 1. Analysis Results for 17 Drinking Water, 16 Advanced Treatment and 3 Process Blank Concentrates. USEPA-600/1-84-020A (NTIS PB85-128221 (1984)

StringWithMarkup.String: DRINKING WATER: Aniline was identified, not quantified, in drinking water in a survey of cities in the US conducted between 1974-1980(1).

Reference: (1) Wegman RCC, DeKorte GAL; Water Res 15: 391-4 (1981)
(2) Greve PA, Wegman RCC; Schriftenr Ver Wasser, Boden-, Lufthyg. Berlin-Dohlem 46: 59-80 (1975)

StringWithMarkup.String: SURFACE WATER: Aniline was detected in the Rhine River and 2 tributaries (The Netherlands) at 2.0-12 ppb avg, 5.5-12 ppb max(1). Aniline was detected in the Meuse River (The Netherlands) 0.62-0.77 ppb avg, 1.6-2.4 ppb max(1). Aniline was detected in Rhine delta water but not in surface water from agricultural areas in the Netherlands(2) and the Waal River at Brackel(4). Aniline was detected in surface water from Germany at concentrations of 0-3.7 ppb(3). Aniline was identified, not quantified, in the Songhuajiang River, China(5). Aniline was identified, not quantified, in the Rhine River Delta, Netherlands(6). Water quality data compiled from the Retrieval (STORET) Data Warehouse and the USGS National Water Information System (NWIS) reports monitoring data for aniline; this chemical was reported as 'Present Below the Quantification Limit' (>10 ug/L) in 167 surface water samples collected by the New Mexico Environmental Department between November 2014 and November 2016, and reported as not detected in 681 surface water samples collected in North Carolina between January 2013 and December 2016(7).

Reference: (1) National Water Quality Monitoring Council. Water Quality Data. Aniline. Available from as of March 26, 2018: https://www.waterqualitydata.us/portal

StringWithMarkup.String: RAIN: Water quality data compiled from the Retrieval (STORET) Data Warehouse and the USGS National Water Information System (NWIS) reports monitoring data for aniline; this chemical was detected at concentrations of 0.13 and 0.24 ug/L in 2 samples of storm water collected by the New Mexico Environmental Department on August5, 2016(1).

StringWithMarkup.String: SEDIMENT: Aniline was not detected in 3 samples of bottom sediment, but was detected in a soil sample at 5 ppm from the Buffalo River, Buffalo, NY(1). StringWithMarkup.String: URBAN/SUBURBAN: Aniline was detected in Raleigh, NC at a concentration of 90 ppb, however data quality is considered questionable(1). Aniline was identified, not quantified, in air 4000 m away from a chemical factory(2).

StringWithMarkup.String: URBAN/SUBURBAN; RURAL/REMOTE : Outdoor air collected at 24 locations in Italy (ranging from urban to rural sites) contained aniline concentrations ranging from 50-425 ng/cu m(1).

Reference: (1) Rampfl M et al; Environ Sci Technol 42: 5217-22 (2008)
(2) Palmiotto G et al; Chemosphere 43: 355-61 (2001)

StringWithMarkup.String: INDOOR: Air samples collected from the interior of a motor vehicle during the autumn of 2006 detected an aniline concentration range of 0.2-1.9 ug/cu m(1). Aniline and other aromatic amines were monitored in the indoor air at 22 locations in Italy including homes and various public sites (both smoking and non-smoking)(2); the highest aniline concentrations of 351 and 483 ng/cu m were recorded in hospital wards(2); no association with smoking vs. non-smoking locations was observable for aniline in contrast to other aromatic amines(2).

Section.Description: Information on the amount or concentration of this compound in food, reported from various data sources.

Reference: (1) Neurath GB et al; Food Cosmet Toxicol 15: 275-82 (1977)
(2) IARC; Some Aromatic Amines, Anthraquinones and Nitroso Compounds, and Inorganic Fluorides Used in Drinking-Water and Dental Preparations. 27: 39-61 (1982)
(3) Yu TH et al; J Agric Food Chem 37: 725-30 (1989)

StringWithMarkup.String: In a study published in 1977, aniline was detected in 14 of 16 samples of fresh fruits, vegetables, salad and maize in Germany at concentrations of 0.6-30.9 ppm; aniline was detected in preserved vegetables from Germany at concentrations of <0.1 ppm and animal feed at 120 ppm(1). Aniline was identified, not quantified, as a volatile component of black tea(2). Aniline was detected in the volatile component of garlic bulbs at concentrations of 0.005-10.52 ppm(3).

StringWithMarkup.String: Aniline is a constituent of various plant parts of a variety of plant species(1).[Table#63]

StringWithMarkup.String: Aniline was detected in the emissions of tufted textile floor coverings with styrene-butadiene rubber at concentrations of 27.6-744 ng/L at temperatures of 23-71 °C(1). Aniline has been identified as a constituent of tobacco, tobacco smoke, and tobacco smoke substitute(2).

(Multivolume work). Available at: https://monographs.iarc.fr/ENG/Classification/index.php, p. V27: 45 (1982)

StringWithMarkup.String: Aniline has been found in tobacco smoke at concentrations of 50.6-577 ng/cigarette. ... It has also been detected in steam volatiles from distillation of leaves of one type of tobacco. ... Aniline has been detected in swine manure: 8.2 ug/L in the raw liquid

Section.Description: Potential way(s) in which people may come into contact with a hazardous chemical.  Examples of common exposure routes are inhalation, ingestion, skin/eye contact.

Reference: (1) US EPA; Chemical Data Reporting (CDR). Non-confidential 2016 Chemical Data Reporting information on chemical production and use in the United States. Available from, as of March 26, 2018: https://chemview.epa.gov/chemview

StringWithMarkup.String: According to the 2016 TSCA Inventory Update Reporting data, 16 reporting facility estimates the number of persons reasonably likely to be exposed during the manufacturing, processing, or use of aniline in the United States may be as low as fewer than 10 workers and as high as 9,999 workers per plant; the data may be greatly underestimated due to confidential business information (CBI) or unknown values(1).

Reference: (1) NIOSH; NOES. National Occupational Exposure Survey conducted from 1981-1983. Estimated numbers of employees potentially exposed to specific agents by 2-digit standard industrial classification (SIC). Available from, as of March 26, 2018: https://web.archive.org/web/20110717195709/https://www.cdc.gov:80/noes/noes1/agt index.html

StringWithMarkup.String: NIOSH (NOES Survey 1981-1983) has statistically estimated that 41,988 workers (14,949 of these were female) were potentially exposed to aniline in the US(1). Occupational exposure to aniline may occur through inhalation and dermal contact with this compound at workplaces where aniline is produced or used. Monitoring data indicate that the general population may be exposed to aniline via inhalation of ambient air, ingestion of food and drinking water contaminated with this chemical, dermal contact with consumer products containing aniline and via inhalation of tobacco smoke(SRC).

Reference: (1) Selden A et al; Int Arch Occup Environ Health 63: 403-08 (1992)
(2) Stettler L E et al; Scand J Work Environ Health 2: 78-81 (1992)
(3) Ward EM et al; J Natl Cancer Inst 88: 1046-52 (1996)

StringWithMarkup.String: Aniline was detected in the workplace air of a power generating plant in Sweden where 4,4'-methylene dianiline was used in an epoxy based curing system at concentrations of less than 1 ug/cu m to 18 ug/cu m(1). Aniline was detected in the urine of workers at an antioxidant and rubber accelerator producing plant at concentrations of 2.7-32.3 ug/L(2). Aniline was reported in the urine of workers at a chemical manufacturing plant in Niagra Falls, NY at mean concentrations of 3.9-29.8 ug/L(3). These workers also had blood hemoglobin levels of aniline of 3,163-17,441 pg/g(3).

Reference: Mackison, F. W., R. S. Stricoff, and L. J. Partridge, Jr. (eds.). NIOSH/OSHA - Occupational Health Guidelines for Chemical Hazards. DHHS(NIOSH) Publication No. 81-123 (3 VOLS). Washington, DC: U.S. Government Printing Office, Jan. 1981., p. 1

StringWithMarkup.String: Aniline can affect the body if it is inhaled, comes in contact with the eyes or skin, or is swallowed.

StringWithMarkup.String: Mean hemoglobin adduct levels of aromatic amines in 12 smokers blood samples were aniline 4.4, o-toluidine 0.10, m-toludine 0.49, p-toluidine 0.13, 22-aminoaphtalene 0.015, and 4-aminobiphenyl 0.17 ng/g. Mean levels of these compound in nonsmokers were 3.8, 0.034, 0.68, 0.070, 0.006, and 0.025 ng/g, respectively.

Literature references related to scientific contents from Springer Nature journals and books. These references have been ranked automatically by an algorithm which calculates the relevance for each substance in a Springer Nature document. It is based on: (1) the TF-IDF, adapted to chemical structures, (2) location information in the text (e.g. title, abstract, keywords), and (3) the document size.  Springer Nature aims to provide only highly qualitative and relevant content but references of lower relevance aren't withheld as they might contain also very useful information.

The Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) tree for this entity.  MeSH is a controlled and hierarchically-organized vocabulary produced by the National Library of Medicine.

ChEBI Ontology tree.  ChEBI is an acronym for Chemical Entities of Biological Interest, which is a freely available dictionary of molecular entities focused on 'small' chemical compounds. ChEBI incorporates an ontological classification, whereby the relationships between molecular entities or classes of entities and their parents and/or children are specified.

Classification of this compound, provided by ChemIDplus, which is a free web search system that provides access to the structure and nomenclature authority files used for the identification of chemical substances cited in National Library of Medicine (NLM) databases. Reference.Name: EPA SRS List Classification
Reference.Description: Substance Registry Services (SRS) is the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) central system for information about substances that are tracked or regulated by EPA or other sources. It is a resource for basic information about chemicals, biological organisms, and other substances of interest to EPA and its state and tribal partners. SRS makes it possible to identify which EPA data systems, environmental statutes, or other sources have information about a substance and which synonym is used by that system or statute.

Reference.Name: EPA TSCA Classification
Reference.Description:
EPA Chemicals under the Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA) collection contains information on chemicals and their regulation under TSCA. The chemical classification tree is created based on the TSCA substance regulatory flag, UVCB, and commercial activity status.
Update: 2024-12-06 12:51:01

Reference.Name: MolGenie Organic Chemistry Ontology
Reference.Description: An organic chemistry ontology developed by MolGenie and OntoChem to assign chemical entities to structural classes, split into three main subsections: calculated properties, compounds and substructural concepts. The ontology contains chemistry structural classes with a focus on elements and small organic compounds, but not inorganic, polymer, biopolymer, metal complexes, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) and other chemistry entities. The ontology has been mapped to several collections of chemicals, including (a) Chemicals of Biological Interest (ChEBI), (b) the ChEMBL database of bioactive molecules, (c) the LOTUS natural product collection, (d) per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) extracted from Barnabas et al (2022) DOI: 10.1039/D2DD00019A (e) PubChemLite and (f) the ZeroPM Global Chemical Inventory.
Reference.LicenseNote: CC-BY 4.0

Reference.Name: SID 403029775
Reference.Description: The PATENTSCOPE database from WIPO includes patent and chemical structure search (with a free account) that gives access to millions of patent documents. The World Intellectual Property Organisation (WIPO) is a specialized United Nations (UN) agency headquartered in Geneva (Switzerland). Our mission is to lead the development of a balanced and effective international Intellectual Property (IP) system that enables innovation and creativity for the benefit of all. We help governments, businesses and society realize the benefits of Intellectual Property and are notably a world reference source for IP information.
